entry.title: Middle Asia Developers Releases Tashkent International Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Middle Asia Developers has recently released their rendition of Tashkent International Airport (UTTT) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, serving Tashkent, in Uzbekistan, with a yearly average of 8.7 million passengers, making it the 8th busiest in the Post-Soviet states. The airportâs first records date back to 1924, when the first passenger flight was completed on a Junkers R-13, flying the Tashkent-Pishpek-Almaty route.Â It eventually evolved into a transportation hub during the Soviet era, embracing the jet age as soon as 1957 with the Tu-104. By 1967, Tashkent had routes to Leningrad (Saint Petersburg), Novosibirsk, Sverdlovsk, Chelyabinsk, Simferopol, certain cities in the Baltic states, the Caucasus, and some in the Far East. â The airport underwent many changes during the post-Soviet era, struggling to cope with the passenger volume. Western construction companies helped out quite significantly during the mid-1990s. Terminal 2 was rebuilt in 2001 to serve over 2 million passengers a year. It has modern waiting lounges, VIP halls, restaurants, bars, duty-free shops, and even a pharmacy. â Terminal 3 was launched a decade after Terminal 2, and it could handle 400 passengers per hour (half the capacity of Terminal 2). â The airport has been expanded in recent years, going from 45,000 square meters to 65,000 square meters of terminal area, allowing it to handle even more passengers per hour. â In August 2024, they finished another expansion project, renovating the airportâs facade while at it. Later that same year, they started expanding the arrivals hall by 2,500 square meters.Â There are plans to merge the arrival and departure terminals by 2026. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom ground textures, custom jetways, a basic interior, and much more. â Itâs available on SimMarket for roughly $18.64, requiring at least 984.50 MB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: Impulse Simulations Releases Port Lincoln Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Impulse Simulations has recently released their rendition of Port Lincoln Airport (YPLC) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, serving Port Lincoln, South Australia, with a yearly average of 199,546 passengers. The airportâs history dates back to World War 2, when it was established as a Royal Australian Air Force training facility for bomber crews. This laid the groundwork for the infrastructure that would eventually become a civil airport in the not-so-distant future. For nine years after the war, the airport remained closed, only reopening as a civilian airport in 1954. It then had a short grass runway and rudimentary passenger infrastructure. During that time period, Adelaide was the only scheduled destination. Eleven years later, the infrastructure saw major improvements with the sealing of the runway and the construction of a new terminal building, attracting airlines such as ASA (Airlines of South Australia) with their Fokker 27s.Â The start of the 21st century led to many changes and improvements as the region saw its demand increase with its growth as a tourist destination. A new terminal was inaugurated in 2013, significantly increasing its passenger handling capabilities and bringing modern amenities. QantasLink and Rex Regional Express are the only airlines currently serving Port Lincoln. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with an accurate terminal model and its respective interior, custom ground textures, custom terrain and vegetation, high-quality PBR texturing, realistic night lighting, custom orthoimagery, performance-friendly optimization, a custom GSX profile, and more. Itâs available on SimMarket for roughly $20.91, requiring at least 996.74 MB of free hard disk space to install. Featuring more than 235 authentic sounds captured exclusively from the MD-80 series, Immersive Audio aims to deliver one of the most detailed and accurate audio experiences available for the type. Developed over eight months, the pack uses 48kHz field recordings to replicate the MD-80âs cockpit atmosphere and mechanical nuances. The pack also features dynamic taxi and landing roll effects, authentic gear operation noises, and smaller quirks, such as FO window wind leak whistling sounds on climbout. Many of these features can be toggled on and off manually from the MD-80âs overhead audio control panel. entry.title: Carenado Announces Beechcraft Baron B55 for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Following its first teaser in a Facebook post earlier this month, Carenado has announced that the Beechcraft Baron B55 will be coming to MSFS 2024. The B55 is known for its stable handling, solid performance, and flexibility for both private and business flying. Further updates have since been shared, including a closer look at the cockpit, featuring an Aspen Avionics EFD1000 unit. The product is also set to feature Carenadoâs new "RealXperienceâ concept, which aims to add extra depth to the flying experience by utilising some of the newer MSFS 2024 features, such as various wear and tear effects, dirt, vibrations, mud buildup, and bug splatters. The Beechcraft Baron family, including the short-body Baron 55, Baron 56, and long-body Baron 58, is a series of piston aircraft evolved from the Beechcraft Travel Air,Â itself a twin-engined development of the Beechcraft Bonanza. Model 55 Barons were produced until the early 80s, with a total of 3,651 units manufactured between 1961 and 1983. While Carenado has not confirmed a release date, more details, including avionics options and other features, are likely to be announced as the project nears completion. entry.title: CRZ Studio Releases The Aeroplane Manufactory Chinook SJ
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Newcomers, CRZ Studio has recently released its first aircraft, the Chinook SJ from the Aeroplane Manufactory. CRZ Studio were founded in 2023 by two brothers, aiming to âbring highly authentic, handcrafted aircraft to the flight sim worldâ.Â The Chinook SJ is an ultralight homebuilt kit aircraft available in two versions: one designed for the 4-stroke Rotax 912UL engine and the other for the 2-stroke Rotax 582UL engine. The 2-stroke version has now been recreated by CRZ Studio in Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, with the 4-stroke version coming at a later date. According to CRZ Studio, the Chinook SJ was developed using actual aircraft assembly manuals, ensuring unmatched accuracy and realism. The developers also claim that the Chinook SJ is the ideal aircraft for exploring remote islands, mountain valleys, and other inaccessible areas, thanks to its exceptional Short Takeoff and Landing (STOL) performance. CRZ Studio has announced a variety of upcoming updates for the Chinook SJ. The future releases will, according to the developer, include a custom sound set for the Rotax 582 and 912 engines, a new sport light DR2 variant, an optional Rotax 912 engine, a floats configuration, optional GPS units, and dynamic effects for dirt, mud, dust, and grime, among other features. A DLC expansion celebrating the record-breaking competition-ready Chinook variant, titled "Dan Reynolds Valdez Special," is also in development. â The Chinook SJ Aeroplane by CRZ Studio is now available for $26.83 on CRZ Studio's website, exclusively for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024. â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon â

entry.title: iniBuilds Updates A350 Airliner for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. iniBuilds has released version 1.1.3 of its Airbus A350 Airliner for MSFS 2020 and 2024, delivering a range of fixes and improvements, across systems, visuals, and sounds. Key changes in v1.1.3 include refinements to the Flight Management System, fixing SEC/F-PLN display issues, VNAV constraint handling, and LNAV sequencing after go-arounds. HUD performance has been improved, with more accurate acceleration cues, proper minimum height indications, and better in-sim alignment. Brake to Vacate logic now responds correctly to runway exit changes, and brake thermodynamics have been adjusted, for slower, more realistic cooling rates. System updates cover electrical, hydraulic, and pressurisation behaviour, including more accurate vent system effects, consistent GPU availability on spawn, and correct yellow electric pump ECAM alerts, on cargo door opening. Stability fixes address WASM-related crashes, tied to custom waypoints and certain procedures, while art updates have resolved cockpit LOD flicker, as well as various floating livery decals. The visibility of exterior lights in the wingtip assemblies has also been improved. Furthermore, OIS enroute maps and Navigraph authentication should now be more reliable, and flap deployment sounds are now more audible across all configurations. In a significant announcement, iniBuilds also confirmed a partnership with Echo 19 Audio Productions, to deliver a complete sound overhaul for the A350. This update will bring richer and more detailed cockpit, engine, and environmental audio, aiming to provide a more immersive soundscape in future releases. entry.title: SHADESCENE Releases Tawau Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. SHADESCENE has recently released their rendition of Tawau Airport (WBKW) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. The airport serves the Tawau Division in Malaysia and has a yearly average of 572,365 passengers. The airport was inaugurated in December 2001, replacing Tawauâs former main airport. It was small and tricky due to its very short runway (one of the shortest in Malaysia), which caused great concern overall.Â The official inauguration only happened two years later, in 2003.Â Its passenger terminal has one and a half stories, with two jetways and the ability to accommodate up to 8 airplanes simultaneously. â Before COVID-19, the airport was operating above maximum capacity, reaching 1.8 million passengers yearly, significantly exceeding its intended 1.4 million passenger capacity. A plan was made to expand it to 2.5 million passengers and upgrade the passenger facilities and overall infrastructure. COVID put a halt to the expansion plans, and in 2022, they were still facing the same issue, constantly suffering from congestion. â In 2023, the government allocated a substantial sum for an improvement program, including extra toilets, an enhanced check-in area, an expanded departure lounge, more retail spaces, and more air conditioning units. A year later, a new plan was announced, encompassing a major expansion set to begin in 2025. The expansion will bring the main terminal from 15,800 square meters to 23,500, add eight new check-in counters, and more. The new capacity would remain aligned with the previous project at 2.5 million passengers annually. â AirAsia, Batik Air Malaysia, Firefly, Malaysia Airlines, and MASwings serve it. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with custom terraforming, custom scenery objects, custom ground textures, custom night lighting, and more. â Itâs available on SimMarket for roughly $14.02, requiring at least 345.46 MB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: iFly Outlines Future Plans, Confirms MSFS 2024 Focus and MAX 9
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. iFly has via Discord released an official development update for its 737 MAX product, outlining planned features for the Service Pack 1 update, as well as its plans for the MSFS 2024 platform. The team made it clear that the SP1 content is still in active development, and that the update will not be released within the next three months. Amongst the changes in SP1 are a more âtablet-styleâ electronic flight bag (EFB), rather than the current Boeing OEM unit, accompanied by CPDLC integration via the Hoppie API, with support for online networks, as well as BATC and SayIntentions, also under review. Other planned features include cabin announcements (with and without GSX), the MAX 8-200 variant, with the typeâs Mid-Cabin Emergency Doors modelled, a visual APU model, an expanded main wheel well model, and an updated fuselage model, rivets and other details. Cabin materials will be redrawn with more texture detail, multiple seating layouts will be offered, and cockpit materials will be refined for better surface type distinction. Landing gear textures will be overhauled, LNAV behaviour will see targeted adjustments, and numerous smaller fixes will be implemented before release. The update also marks a shift in development priorities. SP1 will be the final major release to support MSFS 2020, with all future development moving to MSFS 2024, due to substantial platform differences between the two. Post-SP1 plans include a native MSFS 2024 version of the MAX 9, with the MAX 10 and MAX 7 also under consideration, only after official certification and service entry of those types. While small patches may still arrive for the current MAX 8 for 2020 after SP1, iFlyâs primary focus will be advancing the series for the newer simulator. You can read the full development update on iFly's official Discord server. For all the latest news in flight simulation, be sure to stay tuned on Threshold! entry.title: Carenado Releases Beechcraft Baron B55 for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Carenado has released its Beechcraft Baron B55 for MSFS 2024, available exclusively through the in-sim Marketplace. The light twin-engine aircraft arrives as the latest addition to the developerâs growing MSFS 2024 catalogue. The Baron B55 is a light twin, first introduced in 1961, as part of Beechcraftâs Baron family, which evolved from the earlier Travel Air. Production of the 55 series continued until 1983, with 3,651 units built. Powered by two Continental IO-470-L engines, producing 260 horsepower each, the aircraft is capable of cruising at around 190 knots, with a range of more than 900 nautical miles. Its six-seat layout and twin-engine configuration made it a popular choice for both private and training operations. Carenadoâs rendition of the type for MSFS 2024 includes avionics options such as Aspen Avionicsâ EFD1000, or traditional steam gauges, Garmin GNS530 and GNS430 units, with GTN750/650 compatibility, and the Bendix King KFC 225 autopilot. The package also features eight liveries, plus a paint kit, and an EFB with 2024 interfacing, for switching between avionics configurations. Additional systems modelled include a Garmin GMA 340 audio panel, Garmin GTX 330 transponder, weather radar, and fuel flow indicators. The aircraft is also compatible with MSFS 2024âs Career mode out of the box, with support for missions such as ferry flights and charter services.
